Hi Ben

I’ve just been through the performance part of the new certification and have some feedback.

The example page is _extremely_ simple and will of course with very few adjustments fetch a 90+ score. That example doesn’t really represent the real world scenarios we are met with, when developing HubSpot CMS - where big hero images and videos are at the forefront.

I’ve spent the last two days optimising every part of a client site (not a bought theme) and still we can’t push past 86. Why?

Well, firstly because we have no control over JS files such as banner.js that will be added dynamically in the <head> section of the page regardless of the fact that the cookie banner is disabled in settings. Same goes with forms/v2.js which we can’t control the load method of. Add to that the portalid script which is added twice :/

Secondly because the initial server response time is a whopping *1.14 seconds.* We’re located in Denmark and the site is hosted on (one of?) the european server(s).

Thirdly because the heavily modified bootstrap 2 engine used for sections etc. will output a ludicrous amount of HTML bloat on sites with 6+ sections.

Also I really felt that the presentation of resize_image_url was lackluster and should have had a more thorough walk-through with examples - based on it’s importance and impact on performance scores.

A final note: You’re checking scores in the dev tools simulated Lighthouse tool. If you use the Lighthouse plugin for Chrome instead or <http://pagespeed.web.dev|pagespeed.web.dev> scores will often be lower (and presumably more correct). On the mentioned site we get 6 points lower in the Chrome plugin and pagespeed compared to the dev tool lighthouse test.

Hope it will inspire you to dive deeper in future courses.

Hi <@U03MU3H35R6>! Thanks for writing this up – this is great feedback.

I agree that in the real world, achieving a score of 90+ is going to be not as straightforward as presented in the course.

Thanks for the notes on the HS-loaded resources, and also the feedback on the coverage of the resize_image_url function.

I agree that the lesson as a whole offers fairly shallow coverage of the topic, and performance is a topic that could be rightfully covered in additional videos or multiple lessons.

cc: <@U7SL518D6>
If you happen to take the course survey, we'd also welcome your feedback there – thank you again for taking the course and taking time to write this up :pray:
Thanks Ben. Appreciated. Believe me, I want HubSpot to win :slightly_smiling_face:
